loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruit

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIANTANSO dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec madame AMI débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  BENKADI 2. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir 0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  81 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the BENKADI 2 group are married women and they are, on average, 36 years old with three children each. Most of them live in traditional families in Niantanso, a village located in the commune of Lobougoula, Cercle of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They work with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their eighth farming loan with the institution, and their previous loans have been duly repaid.

Ami, a member of the group, grows maize. In the photo, she is in the standing row, first from the right.  She is planning to use her loan to buy one 50-kilo bag of fertilizers, one can of herbicide, and to cover the cost of plowing on 0.5 hectare of land. After the harvest, she sells her crops in her village and in Sikasso. Her customers are both men and women and they pay her in cash and on credit. Ami is expecting to make an average profit of 81,000 CFA francs per planting season. She will use part of this profit to repay her loan and the interest, and the rest to help her husband with the family's day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and herbicides, and to cover the cost of plowing.

loans.name: Diana Patricia

texts.es:
Diana a pesar de ser madre soltera y tener ciertos problemas de salud, nunca ha dejado de trabajar y luchar por sus hijos. Ella tiene 27 años y a pesar de su condición médica tiene la vitalidad suficiente para atender su negocio y hacerlo productivo.
Ella se dedica a la producción de leche de vaca en zona rural del municipio de Sonson, Antioquia.
Ella es una mujer dedicada y un ejemplo de superación y constancia.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para comprar 2 vacas y así poder darle más impulso a su negocio.
Su mayor sueño es poder darles una vivienda y una vida estable a sus hijos y tener un hogar en el cual prime la convivencia y bienestar.
texts.en:
Diana, in spite of being a single mother and having certain health problems, has never stopped laboring and working hard for her children.  Diana is 27-years old and, in spite of her medical condition, has enough vitality to tend to her business and make it productive. 
Diana makes her living producing cows' milk in rural zone of Sonson, Antioquia.
She is a dedicated woman and an example of self-improvement and determination. 
Diana is currently requesting a loan to purchase two cows and thereby give greater momentum to her business. 
Diana's greatest dream is to give her children a stable house and life and to have a home in which coexistence and well-being come first.

loans.use: to purchase 2 cows for her business.

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 3 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIANTANSO dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec madame FANTA débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  BENKADI 3. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir 0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  81 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the BENKADI 3 group are married women and they are, on average, 39 years old with three children each. Most of them live in traditional families in Niantanso, a village located in the commune of Lobougoula, Cercle of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They work with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their eighth farming loan with the institution, and their previous loans have been duly repaid.

Fanta, a member of the group, grows maize. In the photo, she is in the standing row, second from the left.  She is planning to use her loan to buy one 50-kilo bag of fertilizers, one can of herbicide, and to cover the cost of plowing on 0.5 hectare of land. After the harvest, she sells her crops in her village and in Sikasso. Her customers are both men and women and they pay her in cash and on credit. Fanta is expecting to make an average profit of 81,000 CFA francs per planting season. She will use part of this profit to repay her loan and the interest, and the rest to help her husband with the family's day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, herbicides, and to cover the cost of plowing.

loans.name: Wajasiriamali Group

texts.en:
Anastazia is the mother of four children who all attend school. She is married and is aged in her early thirties. Anastazia  has been selling fruit for six years now. She starts selling her stocks from 08am and works to 07pm daily and is able to make a good profit each month. 

This is Anastazia's fourth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans (all of which were successfully repaid) to improve her business with more varieties of fruit. She earned a profit which she used to cover part of her children's school fees and home food expenses. Anastazia will use her loan to start a fruit selling business in another place. Her ambition is to greatly improve her business and build a nice house. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Wajasiriamali" which totals two members. Both members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to start a fruit selling business in another place.

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 5 membres du groupe  BENKADI 3 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 44 ans, ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à KOLOKOBA  une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur septième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soroyiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec monsieur YOUSSOUF débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme   BENKADI 3. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 8 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 15 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente , payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  2 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 145 0000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’une part de payer son prêt et son interêt d’autre part de contribuer dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the BENKADI 3 group are married men and they are, on average, 44 years old with eight children each. Most of them live in traditional families in Kolokoba, a commune located in the Cercle of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They work with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their seventh maize production loan with the institution, and have duly repaid their previous loans.

Youssouf, a member of the group, grows maize. In the photo, he is in the standing row, first from the right. He is planning to use his loan to buy eight 50-kilo bags of fertilizers, 15 cans of various herbicides, and also to cover the cost of plowing on two hectares of land. After the harvest, he sells his crops in his village and in Sikasso. His customers are both men and women and they pay him in cash and on credit. Youssouf is expecting to make an average profit of 145,000 CFA francs per planting season. He will use part of this profit to repay his loan and the interest, and the rest to cover some of the family's day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, herbicides and to cover the cost of plowing.

loans.name: Benkadi 4 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 4 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIANTANSO dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec madame AWA KLEKAJOU assise à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  BENKADI 4. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir 0,75 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  88 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the BENKADI 4 group are married women and they are, on average, 33 years old with three children each. Most of them live in traditional families in Niantanso, a village located in the commune of Lobougoula, Cercle of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They work with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their eighth farming loan with the institution, and their previous loans have been duly repaid.

Awa Klekajou, a member of the group, grows maize. In the photo, she is in the front row, second from the left.  She is planning to use her loan to buy two 50-kilo bags of fertilizers, one can of herbicide, and to cover the cost of plowing on 0.75 hectare of land. After the harvest, she sells her crops in her village and in Sikasso. Her customers are both men and women and they pay her in cash and on credit. She is expecting to make an average profit of 88,000 CFA francs per planting season. She will use part of this profit to repay her loan and the interest, and the rest to help her husband with the family's day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and herbicides, and to cover the cost of plowing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, sand, cinder blocks, and iron

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.es: Concepción tiene 40 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañera de vida y su  hija de 5 años de edad. Él es un hombre muy trabajador quien trabaja como jornalero desde hace mucho tiempo. De esta forma se gana la vida y lleva el sustento a su hogar. Con el deseo de mejorar sus condiciones de vida solicita este crédito a FUSAI dado que desea encementar el piso de la vivienda. Con el monto solicitado comprará cemento, arena y grava.
texts.en: Concepción is 40 years old. He lives in his own house with his partner and his five-year-old daughter. He is a very hard-working man who has worked as a day labourer for a long time. It is how he earns a living and provides food for his family. With the desire of improving their living conditions, Concepción is requesting this loan from FUSAI in order to cement the floor of his home. With the amount requested, he will buy cement, sand, and gravel.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, and gravel to cement the floor of his home

loans.name: San Judas Tadeo Group

texts.es:
La tradición de los cristianos es algo que caracteriza a la comunidad Vicente Camalote  Oaxaca, el viernes santo el día se inicia  con el viacrucis  acompañando a nuestro señor Jesucristo en su pasión y muerte, dónde la cantidad de personas que se reúnen es sorprendente para ser un pueblo pequeño.

En esta comunidad fue formado el grupo San Judas Tadeo desde hace ya 5 años, lo que dio origen al nombre del grupo es la religión que profesan las integrantes del mismo y al ser San Judas Tadeo un santo muy milagroso; el grupo lo integran 12 personas y cada una de ellas tiene una actividad económica: Felicitas - Venta de abarrotes, Sara - Venta de carne enchilada, Virginia - Venta de abarrotes , Paula -Venta de comida , Inés -venta de ropa y sandalias, Eufemia -Venta de tortillas de mano , Sara M-Venta de calzado por catalogo ,Rosalía -Venta de refrescos , Marisela - Venta de ropa , María - Venta de ropa  , Lucia - Venta de calzado por catalogo y María de los Ángeles - Venta de antojitos.

María de Los Ángeles es integrante del grupo y desde hace ya 18 años se ha dedicado a la venta de antojitos en su casa, está casada con el señor Marcelo persona muy conocida por toda la población de la comunidad. Doña María ha solicitado el préstamo para comprar  sillas y una mesa, gas, platos, sartén, para continuar con su negocio.

La satisfacción de mantener contento al cliente es su principal motivación, la venta de antojitos es los días viernes, sábado y domingo a partir de las 6 de la tarde hasta que el último cliente se retire o los antojitos se terminen, todo lo prepara al momento para ofrecer calidad en la comida.
 
Últimamente ha pensado en poner un estanquillo afuera de una clínica de salud en donde pretender vender los mismos productos pero desde las 7 de la mañana hasta la 1 de la tarde de lunes a viernes.

Los integrantes agradecen a las instituciones que los han visto crecer.
texts.en:
The Christian tradition characterizes the Vicente Camalote community in Oaxaca.  Good Friday starts off with the Stations of the Cross accompanied by "our lord Jesus Christ" in his passion and death.  The number of people who come out for this event is surprising for being in a small town. 

The communal bank "San Judas Tadeo" formed in this community five years ago.  The name of the communal bank came from the religion practiced by its members and from San Judas Tadeo  being a very miraculous saint.  Twelve people make up the communal bank, and each one of them has a business: Felicitas- Grocery Sales, Sara- Meat Enchilada Sales, Virginia- Grocery Sales, Paula- Food Sales, Inés- Clothing and Sandals Sales Eufemia- Handmade Tortilla Sales, Sara M- Catalog Shoe Sales, Rosalía- Beverage Sales, Marisela- Clothing Sales, María- Clothing Sales, Lucia- Catalog Shoe Sales and María de los Ángeles- Snack Sales.

María de Los Ángeles is a member of the communal bank and for 18 years has made her living selling snacks from her home.  She is married to señor Marcelo, who is well-known through-out their community.  Doña María has requested the loan to buy chairs and a table, gas, plates and a pan to continue with her business. 

The satisfaction of keeping her customers happy is doña María's primary motivation.  She sells her snacks on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays from 6:00 in the evening until the last customers leave or she runs out of snacks.  She prepares everything to order to offer quality food.  
 
Recently, doña María has been thinking of setting up a kiosk outside one of the health clinics.  She would sell the same products but from 7:00 in the morning until 1:00 in the afternoon, Monday to Friday. 

The members of this communal bank are grateful to the institutions that have helped them to grow.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and a table, gas, plates, and a pan.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a computer in order to start her own business

loans.name: Steven

texts.en:
Steven is 46 years old and lives in the town of Mubende, Uganda. He is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. For the past five years, Steven has been working hard to manage his clothing boutique.

To help expand his business, Steven has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy suits, trousers, shirts, and skirts. This will help Steven to generate greater profits and increase stock. Steven hopes that in the future he will be able to pay school fees.

Steven is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). This program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Steven who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

loans.use: to buy suits, trousers, shirts, and skirts.

loans.name: Milton

texts.en:
Milton is 34 years old and lives in the town of Mubende, Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past 3 years, Milton has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells rice, posho, sugar, soap, groundnuts, and candles.

To help expand his business, Milton has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more rice, posho, sugar, soap, groundnuts, and candles. This will help Milton to generate greater profits and increase his income. Milton hopes that in the future he will be able to open up a supermarket.

Milton is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Milton who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

loans.use: to buy more rice, posho, sugar, soap, groundnuts and candles.

loans.name: Rupunde

texts.en:
Rupunde is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kasese, in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Rupunde has been working hard to manage her timber business.

To help expand her business, Rupunde has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber, which will help Rupunde to generate greater profits and increase her income. Rupunde hopes that in the future she will be able to have higher profits.

Ropande is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ropande who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more timber.

loans.name: José Ramiro

texts.es:
José de 42 años de edad, es una persona muy reconocida en su comunidad como un hombre responsable y trabajador, a pesar de no contar con un nivel de estudio a logrado sacar adelante a su familia que la conforman una nieta y su hija, actualmente él vive solo con ellas quienes dependen directamente de él, pues sus otros hijos ya son mayores y decidieron formar su propio hogar.
 
José sea dedicado a la agricultura desde sus 13 años de edad, pues tenía que ayudarle a sus padres siendo el mayor de sus hermanos, además de dedicarse a la agricultura, también elabora estructuras metálicas ayudándole a un amigo.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a CREDICAMPO,  es para comprar más fertilizantes para su parcela de maíz. Anteriormente, compro cierta cantidad de insumos pero no le alcanzo a cubrir toda la parcela y se vio en la necesidad de adquirir un crédito fácil y rápido.

Su sueño es establecer una parcela de sandía y poco a poco ir cultivando otros productos como pepino, tomates, repollo, entre otros, para así sacar a la venta y obtener ingresos para sostener a su familia.
texts.en:
José, 42, is a person who is well-recognized in his community as a responsible and hard-working man. Despite not having studied, he has been able to get his family ahead. His family is made up of a granddaughter and his daughter. Currently, he lives alone with them, and they depend directly on him. His other children are already older and decided to form their own households. 

José has been making a living in agriculture since he was 13, since he had to help his parents because he was the oldest of his siblings. Aside from working in agriculture, he also makes metallic structures to help a friend.

The loan he is requesting from CREDICAMPO is to buy more fertilizer for his corn field. Previously, he bought a certain quantity of supplies but they were not enough to cover all of the land, and he found himself needing to acquire a quick and easy loan. 

His dream is to establish a watermelon field and, little by little, start cultivating other products such as cucumber, tomatoes, cabbage, and other things, so that he can sell them and obtain more income to support his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his corn field

loans.name: María Magdalena

texts.es: María tiene 46 años de edad  y es madre soltera de tres hijos de 22 años, 19 años y 13 años de edad. María es una mujer con espíritu emprendedor quien se dedica a la venta de pollos y a la elaboración y venta de carteras elaboradas a base de hilo. María  solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la construcción de un baño para lo cual  necesita comprar  materiales como: ladrillo, cemento, hierro, arena y pago de la mano de obra para la construcción.
texts.en:
María is 46 years old and a single mother with three children (ages 22, 19, and 13). She is a woman with an enterprising spirit. María sells chickens, but she also makes and sells purses out of yarn.

She is requesting this loan from FUSAI so that she can invest in the construction of a bathroom. María needs to buy materials such as bricks, cement, iron, and sand. She will also pay for the labor that is required for the construction.

loans.use: to buy construction materials and pay for labor in order to build a bathroom.

loans.name: Fatima Del Rosario

texts.es:
La satisfacción de las necesidades básicas como la educación y la buena alimentación, son temas que desde adolescente le preocupaban a Fátima, por lo tanto decidió estudiar Desarrollo Social. Es una joven humilde, responsable y honesta, tiene 21 años de edad, está soltera y cursa cuarto año de su carrera en modo sabatino. Hace cinco meses inició a trabajar en una guardería, actividad laboral en la que espera destacarse y adquirir nuevos conocimientos.
Ella solicita el crédito para cubrir los gastos de titulación de la carrera, puesto que no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder costearlo. Deposita su confianza en el financiamiento porque anhela culminar la carrera y ser una profesional de éxito,  para ello tiene que comprobarlo a través de un titulo. Su familia es la que día a día la motiva a seguir adelante y luchar por sus ideales, uno de sus sueños es encontrar un trabajo basado en su carrera para poner a prueba todo lo aprendido y desenvolverse con soltura.
texts.en:
Satisfying basic needs such as education and a proper diet is a topic that Fátima was concerned about as a teenager. For this reason, she decided to study Social Development. This young woman is humble, responsible, and honest. She is 21 years old, single, and in her fourth year of her degree program that she pursues on Saturdays. Five months ago, she began working at a day care center. Through her job, she hopes to do good work and acquire new knowledge.

Fátima is requesting a new loan in order to cover the expenses related to her degree. At the moment, she does not have the necessary funds to afford her education. She places her trust in this loan because she desires to finish her degree and become a successful professional. In order for this goal to happen, she must get certified. Her family provides her the daily motivation to press forward and strive toward her goals. One of her dreams is to find a job that is related to her degree, which would allow her to utilize everything she learned and develop her skills.

loans.use: to pay for expenses related to her degree.

loans.name: Benkadi 5 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 5 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIANTANSO dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec madame DJENEBOU assise à la deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  BENKADI 5. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir 0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  73 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the Benkadi 5 group are married women. On average, they are 32 years old and have three children. Most of them live in traditional families in Niantanso in the town of Lobougoula, Sikasso Cercle, third administrative region of Mali.

They are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to see their farming activities through the rainy season. This is their eighth farming loan with Soro Yiriwaso. Their past loans were repaid. 

They grow corn with Madame Djenebou, who is seated second from the right in this photo of Benkadi 5. With her loan, she will pay for one 50 kg bag of fertilizer, one bottle of herbicide, and labor to maintain 0.5 hectares of land. After the harvest, she sells her crops in the village in Sikasso to men and women and for cash and credit. 

She would like to earn an average monthly profit of 73,000 FCFA per season. This profit will allow her to pay her loan and interest and help her husband with the household expenses.

loans.use: pay for fertilizer, plowing, and herbicides.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es: Francisco es un joven emprendedor de 22 años de edad, Soltero, quien vive en el departamento de Sololá. El se dedica a la agricultura, actividad que ha identificado como potencial en el área donde vive, las principales hortalizas que cultiva (cebolla y papa) por ser las que se adaptan al clima de la región, eligió esta actividad debido a que es rentable y donde obtiene la mayor parte de sus ingresos para ayudar a sus padres. El está solicitando un préstamo de Q 3,000.00 para la compra de insumos agrícolas (Semilla de cebolla y fertilizante) e incrementar su producción.El sueño que tiene es construir su propia vivienda, actualmente vive con sus padres.
texts.en:
Francisco is a young entrepreneur who is 22 years of age. He is single and lives in the Department of Sololá. Francisco engages in agriculture, an activity that is known to have potential in the area where he lives. The main crops that he grows are onions and potatoes, which have adapted to the climate of the region.

Francisco chose this line of work because it is profitable. Most of the income he earns goes toward helping his parents. He is requesting a loan of 3,000 GTQ so that he can buy farming supplies such as onion seeds and fertilizers, which will help to increase his production. His dream is to build a house of his own since he currently lives with his parents.

loans.use: to buy onion seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies to improve her coffee crop.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a 47-year-old married woman. She has five children. She describes herself to be determined. She operates a boutique where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her primary customers are local consumers. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of financial resources. 

She will use the 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) loan to purchase additional stock. Her business goal is to improve and expand her business within five years. This is her first loan from SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock

loans.name: Nateltaaba Group

texts.fr:
Mr  YACOUBA représente le groupe NATELTAABA. Marié, il est père de 05enfants. Le plus âgé a 17ans et le moins âgé a 03ans. Tous vont à l’école et il a 09personnes a sa charge.
Mr fait la boucherie depuis 26ans. Il s’approvisionne à l’abattoir en ville. 
Il veut s’acheter 15pattes et langues de bœufs et des têtes.
Il veut réinvestir ses bénéfices et ambitionne assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mr Yacouba represents the Nateltaaba group. Married, he is the father of five children. The oldest is 17 years old and the youngest is three. All go to school and he has nine dependents. 

He has been a butcher for the past 26 years. He gets his supplies from the slaughterhouse in the city. He wants to buy 15 ox-tongues and feet, and some ox-heads.

He wants to reinvest his profits and aims to ensure his children's education.

loans.use: buy 15 ox-tongues and feet, and ox-heads

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en:
Elchin, 47, has been married for nineteen years. He lives in the region of Fuzuli as an IDP (Internally Displaced Person). With him lives his family, which is supported through his hard work. His wife is a housewife, and his son and daughter are going to school.

Elchin is a taxi driver. He is applying for a 600 AZN loan through Komak Credit Union to buy new tires. He wishes to thank Kiva lenders for their support and assistance. In the future he wants to buy a new car.

loans.use: to buy new tires.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 43 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, with one of them currently in school. For the past 14 years, Susan has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells household commodities. 

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, oil, sodas, juice, mineral water, bread, sweets, soap and detergent, and will help Susan to generate greater profits and have a bigger business. Susan hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business. 

Susan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Susan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, oil, sodas, juice, mineral water, bread, sweets, soap and detergent

loans.name: Jiguisseme 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 6 membres du groupe JIGUISSEME 1 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, ont en moyenne 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à KOLOKOBA  une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur deuxième prêt de production de maïs  avec l’institution de microfinance soroyiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec monsieur AMADOU débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme    JIGUISSEME 1. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 12 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 15 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente , payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  2 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 145 0000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’une part de payer son prêt et son interêt d’autre part de contribuer dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The six members of the Jiguisseme 1 group are married men. On average, they are 33 years old and have five children. Most of them live in traditional families in Kolokoba, a town in Sikasso Cercle, third administrative region of Mali.

They are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to see their farming activities through the rainy season. This is their second corn farming loan with Soro Yiriwaso. Their past loans were repaid. 

They grow corn with Monsieur Amadou, who is standing second from the left in this photo of Jiguisseme 1. With his loan, he will pay for twelve 50 kg bags of fertilizer, 15 containers of herbicide of differing qualities, and labor to maintain two hectares of land. After the harvest, he sells his crops in the village of Sikasso to men and women and for cash and credit. 

She would like to earn an average monthly profit of 145,000 FCFA per season. This profit will allow him to pay his loan and interest and contribute to the family expenses.

loans.use: pay for fertilizer, herbicides, and plowing.

loans.name: Refiko

texts.en:
Refiko wants to pay for her medical expenses, and with a small portion of the loan, buy pesticides for her agricultural plants. She has been suffering from her heart for a very long time. Specialists have said that she needs a surgery; yet, she hasn’t proceeded with it since she doesn't have money for the entire procedure and hospitalization. A visitation to the doctor for the moment would give her an idea of what to decide on. 

Refiko plants and sells beans, onions, wheat and peppers; she’s got also a mule for transportation. They live in a little town in southeastern Albania. Plums, apples and grapes are the most preferred orchards in Refiko’s village, and also, they have cows and sheep.

loans.use: to pay for her heart medical visitation to the specialist and with a small portion of the loan to buy pesticides for her agricultural plants

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Rachael is 40 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Rachael has been working hard to manage her cosmetic shop, which sells cosmetic items. 

To help expand her business, Rachael has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cosmetic items, and will help Rachael to generate greater profits and add capital to the business. Rachael hopes that in the future she will be able to build more rental houses. 

Rachael is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rachael who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more cosmetic items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for educational expenses.

loans.name: Jantoyerela  1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 membres du groupe JANTOYERELA  1 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 48 ans, ont en moyenne 9 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à NIANTANSO un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soroyiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec monsieur YACOUBA débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme JANTOYERELA  1. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 16 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 30 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente , payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  4 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 280 0000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’une part de payer son prêt et son interêt d’autre part de contribuer dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The four members of the Jantoyerela 1 group are married men who on average are 48 years old with nine children, mostly living in traditional families in Niantanso, a village in the circle of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

They work with the  Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution to carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth maize-growing loan with the institution, and all previous loans have been fully repaid.

The crop grown is maize featuring Mr. Yacouba, standing in the second position from the left to the right in the photo of this Jantoyerela 1 group of men. He intends to use the loan to buy 16 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, 30 cans of different kinds of herbicide, and pay for tilling to maintain four hectares (about 10 acres).

After harvest the crop is sold at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit. He expects to achieve an average profit of 280,000 CFA francs per growing season.

This profit will enable him to pay off part of the loan and interest, and on the other hand help with the family's daily expenses.

loans.use: buy fertilizer, herbicide, and pay for tilling

loans.name: Damaris

texts.es:
Damaris es una joven de 34 años de edad, soltera y vive en Cañete con su pequeño hijo.
Al ser madre soltera tuvo que buscar a salir adelante sola, ya que no tenía el apoyo del padre de su hijo. Sin embargo, eso no fue impedimento para que sobresalir.
Actualmente y desde hace más de 2 años trabaja vendiendo queques de excelente calidad y a un buen precio, le va muy bien porque es una persona muy responsable, con mucho entusiasmo en todo lo que hace y con la mayor motivación que puede tener: “Su hijo”.
Damaris está agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado ella podrá comprar una Batidora Industrial y Horno Industrial para que así pueda preparar más rápido sus queques y en mayor cantidad, generando de esta manera mayores ingresos que podrá utilizarlo para ampliar su negocio y poder cumplir su más grande sueño: “formar su propia empresa”.
texts.en:
Damaris is a young 34-year-old, single and lives in Cañete with her young son.  Being a single mother has made it hard to get ahead, and she does not have the support of the father of her child.  But that was no impediment to excel.
 
For the past two years, she has been selling cakes of excellent quality and a good price.  She is doing very well because she is a very responsible person.  There is enthusiasm in everything she does and with  the most motivation you can have, "Your child ".

Damaris is grateful to Kiva lenders because with the support they have given, she can buy an industrial mixer and oven. With this, she can prepare her cakes faster and in greater quantity.  In this way, she will generate more income.  She will use it to expand her business and to fulfill her biggest dream: "to form my own company."

loans.use: to buy a industrial mixer and oven.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 45 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past eight years, Harriet has been working hard to manage her clothing business selling clothes.

To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help Harriet to generate greater profits and pay school fees. Harriet hopes that in the future she will be able to become a landlady.

Harriet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Harriet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes

loans.name: Jack

texts.en: Jack is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself as honest. He operates a retail business where he sells eggs. He has been involved in this business for 12 years. His business is located in a profitable location and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy chickens for egg production. His business goal is to be successful within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be stable. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy chickens for egg production

loans.name: Jerome

texts.en:
Jerome is 36 years old and lives in the town of Fortportal in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 5 years, Jerome has been working hard to manage his transportation business, which deals in the transportation of people. 

To help expand his business, Jerome has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used for car repair, and will help Jerome to generate greater profits and boost the business. He hopes that in the future he will be able to buy a second car. 

Jerome is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jerome who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.


"

loans.use: to pay for car repair and maintenance

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 34 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 7 years, Rosemary has been working hard to manage her bar business. 

To help expand her business, Rosemary has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beers, water and sodas, and will help Rosemary to generate greater profits and add stock to the business. She hopes that in the future she will be able to have a bigger bar in the area. 

Rosemary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rosemary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more beers, water and sodas

loans.name: Specioza

texts.en:
Specioza is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children who are all currently in school. For the past 5 years, Specioza has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells sugar, beers, sodas, wheat flour and oil. 

To help expand her business, Specioza has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, beers, sodas, wheat flour and oil, and will help Specioza to generate greater profits in order to pay school fees and finish her house. She hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a mini supermarket. 

Specioza is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Specioza who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, beers, sodas, wheat flour and oil

loans.name: Tiessiri 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  TIESSIRI 3 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, ont en moyenne 2 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à NIANTANSO dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA  dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance soroyiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec madame ZANTIO débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  TIESSIRI 3. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0,5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 106 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Tiessiri 3 Group are married women who are, on average 38 years old and have two children.  Most of them live in traditional families in Niantanso in the commune of Lobougoula, in Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

During the winter months, the women work to improve their agricultural businesses, so they collaborate with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso.  This will be their eighth loan, the previous loans were all fully and correctly repaid.

Zantio (standing second from the left in the photo) grows maize.  She plans to use her loan to buy two 50kg sacks of fertilizer, one drum of herbicide and pay labour costs to work half a hectare of land.  She sells her produce in the village in Sikasso, to both men and women, on a cash or credit basis.

Zantio expects to earn an average profit of 106,000 francs CFA over the loan period.  She will use this to repay her loan and help her husband provide for the day-to-day expenses of their household.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicide and pay labour costs.

loans.name: Zerida

texts.en:
Zerida is 31 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children with one of them currently in school. For the past 2 years, Zerida has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells sugar, cooking oil, rice, bread and other items. 

To help expand her business, Zerida has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, cooking oil, rice, bread and other items, and will help Zerida to generate greater profits in order to construct a house. She hopes that in the future she will be able to start a poultry house. 

Zerida is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Zerida who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy sugar, cooking oil, rice, bread and other items

La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec madame FATOUMATA débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  TIESSIRI 4. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0,25 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 74 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

The five members of the Tiessiri 4 Group are married women who are, on average, 41 years old and have three children.  Most of them live in traditional families in Niantanso in the commune of Lobougoula, in Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

During the winter months, the women work to improve their agricultural businesses, so they collaborate with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso.  This will be their eighth loan, the previous loans were all fully and correctly repaid.

Fatoumata (standing on the far right in the photo) grows maize.  She plans to use her loan to buy one 50kg sack of fertilizer, one drum of herbicide and pay the labour costs to work a quarter of a hectare of land.  She sells her produce in the village, in Sikasso, to both men and women, on a cash or credit basis.

Fatoumata expects to make an average profit of 74,000 francs CFA over the loan period, which she will use to repay her loan and help her husband provide for the daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicide and pay labour costs.

loans.name: Ekome Feamo 3 Group

texts.en:
These women are part of the Ekome Feamo 3 Group, which consists of four women who all live in the same neighborhood and all perform different activities selling cooking utensils, plates, kettles, cutlery, flour, slippers, cooking oil and charcoal. The group meets once a week.

Leticia is the featured borrower for the group, and she is in her fourth loan cycle. She is active in trading cooking oil and slippers and is requesting the loan to buy more cooking oil and slippers for resale to customers.

She has over seven years experience, and with her income from this business she helps her husband to manage the family expenses and pay for her children's tuition fees. She wants to increase her stock in order to sell more in the neighborhood and to make more profit, so she can put some money into savings.

The group will need a total amount of GHS 3,200 to be able to serve customers better.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil and slippers for resale to customers.

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en:
Phoebe is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Phoebe has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells mineral water, soda, juice, detergent and sugar.

To help expand her business, Phoebe has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy mineral water, soda, juice, detergent and sugar, and will help Phoebe to generate greater profits and increase her stock. Phoebe hopes that in the future she will be able to stock up her shop.

Phoebe is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Phoebe who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy mineral water, soda, juice, detergent and sugar

loans.name: Bonny

texts.en:
Bonny is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, 2 of whom are currently in school. For the past 10 years, Bonny has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Bonny has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help Bonny to generate greater profits and to increase her clothing stock. Bonny hopes that in the future she will be able to have higher profits. 

Bonny is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Bonny who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes

loans.name: Jehovah Group

texts.fr:
Mme CLARISSE MARIE BLANCHE est responsable du groupe JEHOVAH. Mariée, elle est mère de 02enfants. Le plus âgé a 10ans et le moins âgés à 02 ans. 01 va  à l’école. Elle a 05personnes en charge.
Mme  est coiffeuse et vend en même temps des mèches  depuis  11ans.  Elle s’approvisionne au marché de son secteur. Ses clients sont les filles et femmes.
Elle veut s’acheter  50 paquets de mèches.	
Elle veut renforcer son activité avec ses bénéfices. Mme  ambitionne  assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Clarisse Marie Blanche is the leader of the Jehovah Group.  She is married and has two children.  The eldest is ten years old and the youngest is two years old.  One of her children currently attends school.  Clarisse Marie Blanche is responsible for a total of five people.  

She has been a hairdresser for eleven years, and also sells hair extensions.  She buys her supplies at a local market.  Her customers are all women and girls.

Clarisse Marie Blanche wants to buy fifty packets of hair extensions.  In this way, she hopes to improve her business.

Her hope for the future is to be able to pay for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy 50 packets of hair extensions.
