The ten members of the Tiessiri 2 group are married women who on average are 38 years old with three children, mostly living in traditional families in Niantanso in the Lobougoula district, part of the circle of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

They have been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution to carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their eighth loan with the institution, and all previous loans have been fully repaid.

The selected crop is maize featuring Mrs. Kadiatou, sitting in the middle in the photo of this Tiessiri 2 group of women. She intends to use the loan to buy two 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, one can of herbicide, and pay for tilling to maintain one half of an hectare (about 1.24 acres).

After harvest the crop is sold at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit. She expects to achieve an average profit of 86,000 CFA francs per growing season.

This profit will enable her to pay off the loan, and also help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: buy fertilizer, herbicide, and pay for tilling

loans.name: Sabali 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 5 membres du groupe SABALI 2 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, ont en moyenne 7 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à KOLOKOBA  une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Ils collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs ( PPM ) avec l’institution de microfinance soroyiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec monsieur MOUSSA débout au milieu  sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme  SABALI 2. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 12 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente , payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  3 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 190 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’une part de payer son prêt et son interêt d’autre part de contribuer dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the Sabali 2 group are married men who on average are 38 years old with seven children, mostly living in traditional families in Kolokoba, a district in the circle of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

They have been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution to carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth maize-growing loan cycle with the institution, and all previous loans have been fully repaid.

The selected crop is maize featuring Mr. Moussa, standing in the middle of the photo of this Sabali 2 group of men. He intends to use the loan to buy twelve 50-kilo bags of fertilizer, 20 cans of different kinds of herbicide, and pay for tilling to maintain three hectares (about 7.4 acres).

After harvest the crop is sold at village level and in Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women, for cash and on credit. He expects to achieve an average profit of 190,000 CFA francs per growing season.

This profit will enable him to pay off part of the loan and interest, and on the other hand help with the family's daily expenses.

loans.use: buy fertilizer, herbicide, and pay for tilling

loans.name: Siguidia Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe SIGUIDIA ont en moyenne  41 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à KIMPARANA/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des condiments, des céréales, des boissons et des produits divers. Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe SIGUIDIA sont à leur  2ème  prêt solidaire. ASSETOU  femme debout au milieu sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 15Kgs d’oignon, 10Kgs de Sel, 50Kgs de riz, 30Kgs de mil, 10Kgs de patate douce, 1 demi paquet de  Cube Maggi et 10Litres d’huile. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Siguidia Group are, on average, 41 years old and have three children.  They all live in traditional, extended families in Kimparana/Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family and business ties.  They buy and sell food ingredients, cereals, drinks and other products.

This will be the group's second loan from the field partner, the previous loan was fully and correctly repaid. 

Assetou (standing in the middle of the photo) plans to use her loan to buy 15kg of onions, 10kg of salt, 50kg of rice, 30kg of millet, 10kg of sweet potatoes, half a packet of Maggi stock cubes and 10 litres of oil.  She buys her supplies locally and in the surrounding villages, and she sells her products to both men and women on a cash or credit basis.

Assetou expects to earn an average profit of 35,000 francs CFA a month.  She will use this to provide for healthcare costs, food, clothing, school fees, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients and cereals for resale.

loans.name: Azra

texts.en:
Azra is a 46-year-old married lady who has been running a small general store in her community for many years. She offers a variety of grocery items at a reasonable price and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. She makes enough to provide for her family. 

To keep her store fully stocked, she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR which she will use to buy a stock of rice, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates. In this way she will be able to consistently meet the increasing demand. 

She wishes to use part of her revenue to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy stock of rice, sugar and flour.

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz is a 46-year-old married woman and a mother of six. She is a hardworking mother who is helping her family by providing tailoring services in her community. She has been doing this for the past 4 years and she knows the techniques of stitching very well. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community, and she earns enough to lead a decent life. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy a stock of threads in different colors, and packs of zippers, buttons and laces to meet the increasing demand. 

In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenue to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: to buy a stock of threads in different colors, and packs of zippers, buttons and laces.

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: Rubina is 38 years old, a vigorous, married woman. She is the mother of five children. She has had a business doing hand embroidery for the past four years. She is passionate about her work, and client demand is strong. But business challenges, combined with family expenditures, frustrate her nearly every day. Her husband is employed as a salesperson in a grocery store, but he does not earn enough to support his family well. Rubina's embroidery patterns are very popular on her street, and she is the best earning resource in her household. She wants to grow her business. She requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities to meet the increasing demand. She shared her dream of running a training center for girls of her village. She is also interested in opening her own shop in the market to display her work.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities.

loans.name: Mirna Ester

texts.es: Mirna tiene 32 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su esposo y su hija de 7 años de edad quien se encuentra estudiando. Mirna es una mujer muy trabajadora quien posee una pequeña tienda en la cual vende productos como: arroz, frijoles, pan dulce, detergente, aceite, golosinas, etc. De esta forma junto a su esposo mantienen la economía del hogar. Mirna solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la construcción de un muro de retención para proteger el terreno. Con el monto solicitado comprará cemento, arena, ladrillo, etc.
texts.en:
Mirna, 32, lives in her own house with her husband and 7-year-old daughter who attends school.  Mirna is a hard-working woman who has a small store where she sells products such as rice, beans, sweet bread, detergent, oil, sweets, etc.  This is how she and her husband support the household economy.  

Mirna is requesting a loan through FUSAI to build a retention wall to protect her land.  She will use the loan to buy cement, sand, bricks, etc.

loans.use: To buy cement, sand, bricks, etc. to build a retention wall.

loans.name: Progreso 2 Group

texts.es:
La producción de caña es la actividad a la que la mayoría de las personas de Vicente Camalote y las comunidades cercanas se dedican durante todo el año y la molienda de caña por parte del ingenio La Margarita demora 6 meses, mientras que los otros 6 son de reparación.

En Oaxaca varias señoras formaron un grupo para solicitar un préstamo a VisionFund México el nombre del grupo es Progreso 2 comentan que  el nombre lo eligieron porque el préstamo les permite progresar, las integrantes del grupo y sus actividades son las siguientes: Amalia- Venta de productos naturistas, Teresita-Venta de abarrotes, Zenaida- Venta de ropa, Venancia- Venta de Cosméticos, Rafaela- Venta de manualidades (tejido), Benedicta-Venta de antojitos, Anayhely-Venta de antojitos.
Doña Amalia se ha dedicado desde hace ya 4 años a la venta de productos naturistas, tiene su club con el cual ha obtenido muy buenas ganancias. El préstamo solicitado lo utilizará para realizar algunas remodelaciones en el local, comprar  licuadoras, copas, bancos, 2 ventiladores y malteadas de diferentes sabores.
Su gran sueño es constituir una mini cadena de locales en diferentes comunidades y crecer cada vez más.
Sentirse a gusto con lo que hace es lo mejor pues afirma que ayudar a los clientes con los productos  que vende es algo maravilloso.
texts.en:
Sugar cane production is the main business for people living in Vicente Camalote and nearby communities all year round.  Milling the cane at the "La Margarita" factory  takes six months and the rest of the year is for repair.

In Oaxaca there are several women who make up the communal bank "Progreso 2" which is requesting a loan through VisionFund Mexico.  They chose that name because the loan enables them to progress.  The members and their businesses are:  Amalia - natural product sales; Benedicta - snack sales;  and Anayhely - snack sales.

Amalia has been selling natural products for four years.  She has a club and earns a good profit.  The loan she is requesting is to renovate parts of her locale, and buy juicers, glasses, benches, two fans and different flavored malts.

Her greatest dream is to establish a mini-chain of locales in different communities and expand more.  She enjoys what she does because she says it is wonderful to help people with the products she sells.

loans.use: To renovate her locale, and buy juicers, glasses, benches, two fans and different flavored malts.

loans.name: Astan

texts.fr:
Née en Décembre 1952 à San   cercle de San, ASTAN  n’as pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, elle a vite embrassé les activités génératrices de revenus. Elle est mariée et  mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit chez son époux dans le quartier Santoro I de la préfecture de San.  
Elle s’est basée sur la vente de l’encens en gros et en détail  qu’ elle a appris  auprès de sa mère durant 10 ans, et l’exerce actuellement pour elle même à la maison et au marché  depuis 7 ans.  Elle est très sollicitée lors  de la foire de San.  
Afin de diversifier son activité, elle décida de faire recours à l‘institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année .   Elle est à son 2è prêt  individuel. Mme ASTAN compte acheter une quantité importante de l’encens. Elle s’approvisionne  auprès des commerçants grossistes à San, et  revend tous les jours au grand marché et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants à une clientèle mixte au comptant et souvent à crédit. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser le prêt, utiliser  le reste pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants , acheter la nourriture et réinvestir le reste dans son activité de revenus .
texts.en:
Born in December 1952 in San (San Cercle), Astan did not have the opportunity to go to school. She quickly embraced revenue generating activities. She is married and has five children. She lives with her spouse in the Santoro I neighborhood in San prefecture. 

She does wholesale and retail sales of incense. Over the course of 10 years, she learned this trade from her mother. She has been selling incense on her own for seven years. She is very sought after during the San fair.

In order to diversify her activities, she turned to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso last year. This is her second individual loan. 

Madame Astan will buy a large quantity of incense. She buys her supplies from the wholesalers in San. She sells every day in the San market and weekly in neighboring villages’ fairs. She sells to a mixed clientele for cash and often for credit. 

She will earn an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA that she will use to repay the loan. She will use the remaining funds to pay for her children's schooling, pay for food, and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: buy incense.

loans.name: Melisa

texts.es:
Flor esta muy agradecida con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada, comprar una pequeña cama para su bebe de un año, ya que actualmente duerme junto a ella , asimismo realizara la compra de enseres para su hijo y de esta manera podrá ir mejorando su calidad de vida de su pequeño.

Para poder salir adelante Flor trabaja como vendedora en una farmacia de su ciudad y de esta manera puede tener ingresos para solventar los gastos de su hogar y poder luchar por hacer realidad su gran sueño:” Darle una buena educación a su hijo y una vida digna”
texts.en:
Flor is very grateful to Kiva lenders because thanks to their help she can buy a small bed for her one-year-old baby who now sleeps with her.  She will also be able to buy other articles for her son and continue improving his quality of life.

In order to get ahead, Flor works as a sales clerk in a pharmacy in her city.  This allows her to earn an income to cover household expenses and work toward her dream: "To give her son a good education and a dignified lifestyle".

loans.use: To buy a bed and articles for her home.

loans.name: Los Rosales Group

texts.es:
En Oaxaca hay una región donde el clima predominante es cálido con lluvias en verano por lo cual la mayor parte de los habitantes es productora de caña o trabaja en el campo.

María Del Rosario es integrante de un grupo llamado Los Rosales, decidieron ponerle ese nombre pues la casa donde se hacen las reuniones tiene muchas rosas y a la familia, dueña del lugar, también la conocen como Los Rosales (aunque no es su apellido). María se ha dedicado desde hace ya 3 años a la elaboración de bisutería de oro laminado y cristal cortado, con las ganancias apoya a su madre con los gastos de la casa, el préstamo solicitado lo utilizara para invertirlo en la compra de hilos ,piedras, remaches, palitos y las piezas que le son necesarias para la elaboración de pulseras, aretes, collares, espera incrementar su producción y ventas para con ello establecerse en un local.
Sus compañeros se dedican a diferentes actividades, Ana-Venta de Refrescos, Lidia-Venta de pollo, Margarita-Venta de servilletas, Guadalupe-Calzado y ropa por catalogo, Luis Alberto-Venta de pan, Luis Enrique-Venta de refrescos, Lourdes-Venta de ropa y Carlos-Chofer de maquinaria.
texts.en:
Oaxaca is a region where the climate is mainly warm and rainy in the summer, so most of the local people work in sugar cane production or in agriculture.

Maria del Rosario is a member of the communal bank called "Los Rosales".  They decided on this name because of the abundance of roses around the house where they hold their meetings, and also because the family who owns the property is known as "Los Rosales" even though that is not their name.  For three years, Maria has been making gold plated and cut glass jewelry.  With her profits she helps her mother with the household expenses.

The loan she is requesting is to buy thread, beads, rivets, sticks and other pieces she needs to make bracelets, earrings, and necklaces.  She hopes to increase production and sales so she can open a shop.

The other members of the group are involved in different businesses:  Ana - soft drink sales; Lidia - chicken sales; Margarita - napkin sales; Guadalupe - shoes and clothing by catalogue; Luis Alberto - bread sales; Luis Enrique - soft drink sales; Lourdes - clothing sales; and Carlos - machine operator.

loans.use: To buy thread, rivets, cut glass beads, and gold plated metal to make bracelets and earrings.

loans.name: Kreisky Randy

texts.es:
Kreisky es un joven emprendedor, con 22 años de edad, soltero y vive en el Departamento de Ucayali junto a su familia.
Desde hace más de 2 años trabaja como Apoyo de mantenimiento en los pozos subterráneos. También se dedica a la venta de ropa, y le va muy bien debido a que es una persona honrada, trabajadora y a su corta edad ya tiene muchos proyectos planeados que le gustaría ejecutarlos en un futuro no muy lejano.
Kreisky está agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que con el apoyo brindado él podrá remodelar su casa, tarrajear y pintar las paredes, así como arreglar las ventanas y la puerta; de esta manera sentirá mayor comodidad y seguridad y trabajando con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación podrá cumplir su mayor sueño: “Tener su propio negocio y sacar adelante a su familia”.
texts.en:
Kreisky is an enterprising young man. He is 22, single, and lives in the Ucayali region of Peru with his family.
For more than 2 years he has worked in maintenance support for underground wells. He also works selling clothing, and he is very successful because he is honest and hardworking. At his young age he already has many projects planned that he would like to get working on soon. 
Kreisky is thankful to Kiva lenders, because with this loan he will be able to remodel his house, plaster and paint the walls, and also fix the windows and door. This way he will feel more comfortable and by working with great effort and dedication he will be bale to realize his greatest dream, which is to have his own business and do well for his family.

loans.use: remodel his home, plaster and paint the walls, and fix the windows and door.

loans.name: Los Azares Group

texts.es:
Los Azares se ha convertido en una segunda familia para todas la integrantes del grupo quienes se conocen desde hace ya mucho tiempo.

Doña Juana es enfermera aunque hoy en día ya no ejerce con su profesión misma que dejo hace ya algunos años con el firme propósito de ayudara a su hija quien es madre soltera. La niñez de doña Juana fue muy divertida, le gustaba montar a caballo, ordeñar vacas, darle de comer a los pollos, desde hace 30 años se ha dedicado a la venta de comida en una cocina económica que esta ubicada a un lado del ingenio Motzorongo, con las ganancias obtenidas logro darle estudio a sus hijos. Igualmente, con ayuda de su esposo ha reconstruido su casa poco a poco, con el préstamo otorgado comprara, aceite, arroz, frijol, azúcar, jamón, huevos, refrescos, sabritas, galletas, arina,  pan molido etc.
Mientras que sus compañeros se dedican a diferentes actividades, Eulogio- Estética, Rosa Carmela-Venta de refrescos, Irma-Venta de ropa, María Teresa-Venta de ropa, Miriam-Venta de comida, Ana-Venta de Refrescos, Griselda-Venta de pollo, Miguelina-Venta de pollo.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Los Azares" has become a second family for all the members of the group who have known each for a long time.

Juana is a nurse although she no longer works in the profession because she quit her job to help her daughter who is a single mother.  Juana's youth was very enjoyable as she loved to ride horses, mik cows and feed the chickens.  For 30 years she has been selling food at a soup kitchen located next to the Motzorongo factory.  With her profits she has been able to give her children an education.  She also has helped her husband build their home little by little.  The loan she is requesting is to buy oil, rice, beans, sugar, ham, eggs, soft drinks, snacks, cookies, flour, bread crumbs, etc.

The other members of the group are involved in different businesses:  Eulogio - esthetics; Rosa Carmela - soft drink sales; Irma - clothing sales; Maria Teresa - clothing sales; Miriam - food sales; Ana - soft drink sales; Griselda - chicken sales; and Miguelina - chicken sales.

loans.use: To buy oil, flour, tomato, beans, ham, cheese, chili peppers, gas, firewood, onion, pork, beef, chicken, lard and rice.

loans.name: Osmar Javier

texts.es:
Osmar, se decidió por un nuevo crédito para invertirlo en el cultivo de hortalizas y necesita los diferentes materiales que le permitan continuar aumentando su productividad y generando las ganancias con las que cubre las necesidades básicas de su familia y cancela la deuda adquirida, comprara semilla (ejote, pepino, tomate, pepino y chile), fertilizantes, abono, insecticida y plaguicidas.
Utilizo el préstamo anterior para comprar insumos agrícolas, su negocio ha tenido buena productividad y ha logrado abastecer a sus clientes.
texts.en: Osmar decided to ask for a new loan to invest in planting vegetables and he needs various supplies that will allow him to continue increasing his productivity and generating the income that he uses to cover his family's basic needs and to pay off his debts. He will buy green bean, cucumber, tomato and pepper seeds, and fertilizers, manure, insecticide and pesticides. He used the previous loan to buy agricultural supplies, his business has been productive, and he has been able to meet his customers' needs.

loans.use: buy green bean, cucumber, tomato and pepper seeds, and fertilizers, manure, insecticide and pesticides.

loans.name: Estrella Dorada Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad de Oaxaca, el clima predominante es templado húmedo con lluvias en verano. Algunos de los atractivos turísticos de este lugar son La tradicional "Feria de la Caña" efectuada durante el mes de mayo al finalizar la cosecha y la fiesta de "Corpus Cristi" efectuada el 15 de junio. 

El grupo Estrella dorada está formado por 7 integrantes: Cinthia-Venta de Ropa, Elizabeth-Venta de ropa, Francisca- Elaboración y venta de servilletas, Cristina-Venta de tamales y esquites, Edgardo-Venta de refrescos, Juan-Venta de refrescos y Raquel- artesanías bordadas.


Doña Raquel se ha dedicado desde hace ya 10 años a la elaboración y venta de servilletas y manteles  los cuales borda y teje ella misma, comenta que desde que era pequeña observaba como  lo hacía su mamá, quien le enseño el arte y ahora al hacerlo siempre la recuerda. Con el préstamo otorgado comprará, agujas, bastidores, hilos para bordar y para tejer, servilletas y manteles, con las ganancias apoya a su esposo con los gastos.
texts.en:
In a community in Oaxaca, the climate is temperate and humid with rains in summer. Some of the tourist attractions in this area are the traditional Sugar Cane Festival held during the month of May to end the harvest and the Corpus Cristi celebration held on the 15th of June.

The Estrella dorada group is made up of 7 members: Cinthia - clothing sales, Elizabeth - clothing sales, Francisca - production and sales of serviettes, Cristina - sales of tamales and toasted corn snacks, Edgardo - sales of beverages, Juan - sales of soft drinks and Raquel - embroidered crafts.

Raquel has earned a living for the last 10 years making and selling serviettes and tablecloths that she embroiders and knits herself. She comments that when she was young she used to watch how her mother, who taught her the art, used to do it, and when doing it now she always remembers her.  With this credit she will buy needles, frames, thread for embroidery and knitting, serviettes and tablecloths. With the earnings she will support her husband with household expenses.

loans.use: to buy thread, needles, tablecloths, serviettes, frames and hooks.

loans.name: Ana Cecilia Del Carmen

texts.es: Ana tiene 53 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañero de vida. Ella se dedica a la venta de pan dulce y productos de belleza por catalogo. Tienen 13 años de dedicarse a este negocio por lo que ya cuenta con mucha experiencia y muchos clientes que  cada día la prefieren más. Ana solicita este crédito a FUSAI dado que desea reparar las puertas de la vivienda que se encuentran deterioradas. Espera poder contar con dicho financiamiento.
texts.en: Ana is 53 years old and lives in her own home together with her partner.  She earns a living selling sweet breads and through catalogue sales of beauty products.  She has been working in this business for 13 years and therefore has a lot of experience and many customers who prefer her everyday more. Ana requests this loan from FUSAI because she would like to repair the doors on her house as they are deteriorated. She hopes that the loan will be granted.

loans.use: to buy doors for her home.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is thirty years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married with four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Richard has been working hard to manage his spare parts business. 

Richard has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more spare parts, and will help him to generate greater profits and expand the business. Richard hopes that in the future he will be able to become a wholeseller. 

Richard is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Richard who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts like bolts, tyres and wires

loans.name: Al- Batra Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al- Batra. It comprises of four women. They live in Sana'a, Yemen. This community is hard working and they work as much as they can in order to improve their living conditions. They took out a loan of 320,000 YER from AMB.

Iman is the leader of the group. She is a thirty-one years old and married. Her oldest child is six years old and the youngest one is four years old. She lives with her children in Sana'a city. She is a hard working woman who dreams of providing her children with better living conditions. Unfortunately, the country experiences many crises. One of these crises is to do with electricity. Around the country, most people live in darkness most nights. Electricity is one of the biggest problems in Yemen, especially thesedays. For this reason Iman applied for a loan of 90,000 YER from AMB to purchase a power generator for the house. In addition, she hopes to purchase some furniture for the house. 

Iman looks forward to improve the living standards of her family. She also hopes for stability in her country.

loans.use: to purchase a power generator and some furniture for the house

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom is forty-five years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married with four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Tom has been working hard to manage his produce business, which sells produce items like millet, sorghum and rice. 

To help expand his business, Tom has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more millet, sorghum and rice, and will help Tom to generate greater profits and expand on the business. Tom hopes that in the future he will be able to develop his business. 

Tom is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Tom who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more millet, sorghum and rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a kiosk and clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy iron for use in his business.

loans.name: Shahla

texts.en: Shahla is thirty-seven years old, married and lives in the Füzuli region of Azerbaijan with her family. For twenty years, they have been internally displaced persons from Füzuli city. She has two children, her son is eleven years old (he is going to fifth class this year) and her daughter is nine - she is in primary school. Shahla has a few cows. She prepares dairy products (milk, cheese, yogurt etc) and sells them in the local bazaar to earn money for covering family expenses. Today she needs 2,300 AZN to repair her cows' stall, which is in danger of falling down. Shahla gives her thanks to Kiva for its help. She is planning to buy more cows and to increase her business in the future. She hopes that this will grow her monthly income and allow her children to have a good education.

loans.use: repair the cow stall

loans.name: Khalida

texts.en: Khalida is a thirty-seven-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store at the corner of her house. She has two years of experience in this field. She has become known in her area for providing good quality products. She is the mother of two children and is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing and health. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of PKR 40,000 to buy packs of salts, biscuits, oil and beverages to meet the increasing demand at her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: buy packs of salts, biscuits, oil and beverages.

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe BADEGNA ont en moyenne  47 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à MEDINE l’un des quartiers de la ville de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des condiments, des céréales et des produits divers. Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe BADEGNA sont à leur  6ème  prêt solidaire. AWA 1ère femme de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter  50Kgs de lait en poudre, 1 carton de lait concentré et 30Kgs de sucre. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 12 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Badegna Group are, on average, 47 years old and have five children.  They all live in traditional, extended families in the neighbourhood of Medine, in the town of San/Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family and business connections.  They buy and sell food ingredients, cereals and other products.  

This will be the sixth loan for the Badegna Group from the field partner.  The previous loans were all fully and correctly repaid.

Awa (standing on the right in the photo) plans to use her loan to buy 50kg of powdered milk, one box of concentrated milk and 30kg of sugar, from wholesalers.  She sells her products to both men and women, for cash or on credit.  She expects to make an average monthly profit of 12,000 francs CFA, which will be used to pay for healthcare, food, clothing, school fees, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy various products for resale.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe BENKADI ont en moyenne 42 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à MEDINE l’un des quartiers de SAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales et des produits divers.
Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe BENKADI sont à leur  8ème  prêt solidaire. FANTA 1ère  femme de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 100Kgs d’arachide. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 18 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi Group are, on average 42 years old and have four children.  They live in traditional, extended families in the Medine district of San, in Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family and business ties.  They buy and sell cereals and other products.

This will be the eighth group loan for these women, the previous loans were all fully and correctly repaid.

Fanta (standing on the left in the photo) plans to use her loan to buy 100kg of peanuts.  She buys her supplies locally and in the surrounding villages.  She sells to both men and women, on a cash or credit basis.

Fanta expects to make an average monthly profit of 18,000 francs CFA, which will be used to pay for healthcare and school costs, buy food and clothing, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy cereals for resale.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe BENKADI ont en moyenne  42 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à TOMINIAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales, des condiments et des habits. Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe BENKADI sont à leur  8ème  prêt solidaire. FATIMA 2ème  femme de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter   5 pièces de Wax, 10 jupes, 20 foulards et 20 pantalons. Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi Group are, on average, 42 years old and have four children.  They all live in traditional, extended families in Tominian, in Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through family and business ties.  They buy and sell cereals, food ingredients and clothing.

This will be the eighth group loan for the women, with the field partner, the previous loans were all fully and correctly repaid.

Fatima (standing second from the left in the photo) plans to use her loan to buy five wax pagnes (traditional, wrap-around clothing), ten skirts, twenty scarves and twenty pairs of trousers.  She buys her stock from local wholesalers.  Her customers are both men and women and she sells on a cash or credit basis.

Fatima expects to earn an average monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA, which she will use to pay for healthcare costs and school fees, buy food and clothing, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 44-year-old lady who enjoys doing hand embroidery. She started doing this work with her daughters. Her embroidery patterns are very popular in her area. Nasreen makes beautiful patterns for the people in her community. Her designs are much in demand and she has managed to build a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her home. 

To help Nasreen continue her operations, she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to buy reels of thread in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and needles. In this way, she will be able to cater to more customers consistently. Nasreen hopes to increase her income by targeting more customers. Nasreen is in her fourth loan cycle and has a good credit history.

loans.use: to buy reels of thread in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and needles.

loans.name: El Nacaxtle Group

texts.es:
En el estado de Oaxaca hay un árbol llamado Nacaxtle; mide hasta 30 m de alto y hasta 3 m de diámetro, tiene hojas en forma de pluma de avem a su vez compuesta por más hojitas finas y en conjunto alcanzan hasta 40 cm de largo. El fruto del Nacaxtle son vainas de color café oscuro, brillante, de olor y sabor dulce.


De este árbol surgió el nombre del grupo El Nacaxtle cuyos integrantes son; Miriam– Club nutricional, Alicia – venta de comida, Karina– venta de juguetes, Natali– venta de ropa, Haidee – venta de accesorios de plata, Gilberto– venta de suplementos alimenticios, Dorotea – venta de comida, Carmelita–servicio de costura, Julia– venta de bisutería y Elvira - renta de trajes.

Elvira quien desde hace ya 7 años se ha dedicado al servicio de renta de trajes para cualquier evento siendo sus clientes principales los chambelanes y alumnos cuando son clausuras, con las ganancias obtenidas sustenta su hogar y esta pensando en comprarse una máquina para comenzar a costurar, el préstamo lo utilizará para la compra de porta trajes, y mandar algunos trajes a la tintorería puesto que las clausuras se acercan y algunas escuelas ya la han contactado.
texts.en:
There is a tree called Nacaxtle that grows in the state of Oaxaca. It can grow up to 30 m tall [100 ft.] and be up to 3 m [10 ft.] wide. Its leaves look like feathers and some of them can be 40 cm long [16 in.]. The fruit of this tree comes in a shiny brown pod and it has sweet smell and taste.

This group took its name from this tree and its members are Miriam (who sells dietary supplements), Alicia (who sells food), Karina (who sells toys), Natali (who sells clothes), Haidee (who sells accessories in silver), Gilberto (who sells dietary supplements), Dorotea (who sells food), Carmelita (who is a seamstress), Julia (who sells imitation jewelry) and Elvira (who rents dresses).

Elvira has been renting dresses for any occasion for seven years. Her customers are mainly dance partners or students who are having their graduation ceremonies. With the profits she makes, she sustains her family and is thinking of buying a sewing machine to start making dresses.

She will use this loan to buy garment bags and send some dresses to the dry cleaner. Schools will soon have their graduation ceremonies and some have already contacted her.

loans.use: to buy garment bags and send some dresses to the dry cleaner.

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine is 38 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa, which is in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past 15 years, Augustine has been working hard to manage his milling/food processing business. 

To help expand his business, Augustine has requested a loan of 4,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy rice and a new milling machine, and it will help Augustine to generate greater profits and increase his business. Augustine hopes that in the future he will be able to have more milling machines. 

Augustine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP), which primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Augustine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but who have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy rice and a new milling machine.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a married man. He has 4 children, ranging in ages from 15 to 28. He describes himself as determined and diligent. 

Peter operates a farm where he produces milk for sale. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in an ideal location for farming. He describes his biggest business challenge as a lack of capital. 

Peter will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy animal feed. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. He hopes that, in the future, he will benefit from the loan. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy animal feed.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: At the age of 43, Shamim is a hardworking, married woman who has a business selling animals. She buys baby goats and calves at low prices, brings them up and then sells them in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. Currently she is applying for a loan of 30,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR). This will help her to buy more cattle. She aspires to save money so she can provide a better standard of living to her family members.

loans.use: to buy more cattle.
